notes.title: Precis Writing: Template, Title & Compression Rules
notes.content: Use a repeatable 4-sentence précis template (author/context → thesis → key supports → purpose/tone). Compress to ~1/3 without commentary. Always craft a precise, theme-capturing title.
keyTakeaways: Keep author's intent and logical order intact.
Delete examples, figurative language, digressions; keep core claims.
Title should reflect the controlling idea, not a catchy phrase.

notes.title: Precis Practice on Real CSS Passages
notes.content: Practice summary + title on authentic CSS passages from 2000–2025. Compare with model solutions to calibrate length and coverage.
keyTakeaways: Time yourself: 35–40 minutes (incl. title, outline).
Reverse-check: each précis sentence maps to logical blocks in original.

notes.title: Comprehension: Main Idea, Inference, Tone
notes.content: Success depends on quickly extracting thesis, tracking paragraph claims, and answering evidence-based questions (definition-in-context, inference, purpose).
keyTakeaways: Skim → map topic sentences → annotate linking words.
Answer with text evidence; avoid outside knowledge.

resources.title: CommonLit — Text Library (free)

notes.title: Punctuation Mastery: Comma, Semicolon, Colon, Dash
notes.content: Most MCQ and correction errors stem from run-ons/comma splices and misused colons/semicolons. Drill rule → example → short practice.
keyTakeaways: Colon = explanation/list; semicolon = join related ICs.
Prefer precise punctuation over commas everywhere.

notes.title: Subject–Verb Agreement & Sentence Anatomy
notes.content: Agreement traps: intervening phrases, collective nouns, relative clauses, 'as well as'. Build from clause identification to agreement fixes.
keyTakeaways: Find the simple subject; ignore interrupters.
Plural-sounding phrases ('as well as', 'together with') don't make the subject plural.

notes.title: Prepositions: Collocations That Exams Love
notes.content: Errors cluster around verb–preposition pairs (agree with/on, annoyed at/with, bound for). Build a personal list from credible grammar sources.
keyTakeaways: Memorize by collocation, not isolated rules.
Check dictionary examples to confirm register.

resources.title: Cambridge Dictionary — Main Site (with Grammar)
resources.description: Examples & Grammar section for preposition patterns

notes.title: Active ↔ Passive Voice: When & How
notes.content: Know the form (be + past participle) and when passive is stylistically appropriate. Exam items often test passive to active conversion.
keyTakeaways: Prefer active for clarity; use passive for emphasis on action/receiver.
Fix dangling agents: add 'by + agent' only if it adds information.

notes.title: Reported (Indirect) Speech: Tense/Deixis Shifts
notes.content: Convert quotes to reported speech: adjust pronouns, time/place words (now→then, here→there) and backshift tenses when needed.
keyTakeaways: No backshift if the fact remains true at reporting time.
Commands → 'to-infinitive'; questions → if/whether + clause.

resources.title: Khan Academy — Reported Speech & Parallel Structure

notes.title: Parallelism: Make Structures Match
notes.content: Lists, correlative pairs (not only…but also), and comparisons must maintain grammatical symmetry. A top source of correction items.
keyTakeaways: Align word forms (gerund: walking, running, swimming).
In comparisons, keep like-to-like (those of, that of).

notes.title: Sentence Correction: High-Frequency Error Types
notes.content: Target: faulty comparisons, pronoun reference, modifier placement, redundancy ('unless you don't'), article errors.
keyTakeaways: Read aloud for logic and agreement.
Apply one edit at a time; avoid over-correction.

resources.title: Khan Academy — SAT Writing: Grammar Practice Hub

notes.title: Vocabulary: Academic & Exam-Style Wordbanks
notes.content: Prioritize academic and high-frequency lists. Learn via contexts and collocations, not isolated definitions.
keyTakeaways: Maintain a personal 'tricky words' log with synonyms/antonyms.
Study affixes; guess meaning by morphology.

notes.title: Confused Word Pairs & Precise Usage
notes.content: CSS often targets pairs like adverse/averse, eminent/imminent, venal/venial. Use trusted learner dictionaries with examples.
keyTakeaways: Check part of speech + example sentence.
Log minimal pairs with a contrastive sentence each.

notes.title: Idioms & Phrasal Language (for Usage-in-Sentence)
notes.content: Prepare 100–150 high-utility idioms with meaning + self-made sentence. Focus on current usage.
keyTakeaways: Avoid cliché overload; use naturally.
Prefer dictionary-verified definitions.

notes.title: Cohesion vs. Coherence: Glue Your Writing
notes.content: Cohesion = lexical/grammatical ties (reference, substitution, transition signals); coherence = logical organization and flow.
keyTakeaways: Use given→new sequencing across sentences.
Audit transitions; avoid mechanical overuse.

notes.title: Paraphrasing & Summarizing Without Plagiarism
notes.content: Combine synonym shifts + grammar changes + condensation; cite ideas if required. Practice on short academic paragraphs.
keyTakeaways: Change structure first, then words.
Check against source for unintended copying.

resources.title: Oxford Online English — How to Summarise a Text (video)

notes.title: Plain English: Style That Scores
notes.content: Markers reward clarity and economy. Apply plain-English principles to précis, answers, and correction tasks.
keyTakeaways: Short, direct sentences; cut nominalizations.
Prefer concrete verbs; avoid vague bureaucratese.

resources.title: Plain English Campaign — Free Guides
resources.description: How to write plainly + alternative words

notes.title: Pakistan Editorial Reading: Daily Language Diet
notes.content: Regular op-eds sharpen comprehension, vocabulary-in-context, and précis instincts. Read, annotate, and mimic headline→lede→argument structure.
keyTakeaways: Summarize each editorial in 2–3 lines.
Collect 5–10 idioms/phrases weekly from editorials.

notes.title: Official Syllabus, Rules & Past Paper Access
notes.content: Always align prep with FPSC's current syllabus and paper structure; mine official past papers for pattern repetition.
keyTakeaways: Check latest FPSC notices before exam cycle.
Rehearse under 3-hour conditions.

notes.title: Idioms & Usage: Trusted References
notes.content: Use dictionary-grade sources for meanings, registers, and examples. Avoid meme lists.
keyTakeaways: Verify idiom currency and form (e.g., fixed prepositions).
Note register (informal, spoken, AmE/BrE).

notes.title: Reading for Style & Argument (Longform)
notes.content: Long reads train sustained comprehension and précis discipline. Read weekly and write a 120–150 word abstract.
keyTakeaways: Extract thesis + 2–3 supports + conclusion.
Practice neutral tone in summaries.

resources.title: Economist Education — Writing with Style (about guide)

notes.title: Exam-Fit Punctuation & Mechanics Drills
notes.content: Use digital SAT grammar sets to simulate CSS correction timing and error types.
keyTakeaways: Aim >80% on unit tests before moving on.
Review wrong answers to categorize error types.

resources.title: Khan Academy — SAT Reading & Writing Hub

notes.title: Urdu → English Translation: Strategy & Sources
notes.content: Translate for sense, not word-for-word. Preserve metaphors by equivalent expression. Keep tense, aspect, and idiomatic tone natural in English.
keyTakeaways: Render proverbs as sense-equivalents; footnote literal only if asked.
Prefer Anglo-style syntax (SVO, light verbs) over literal calques.

notes.title: Editorial Vocabulary-in-Context (News Review)
notes.content: Mine current news phrases/idioms weekly; attach example sentences from authentic media.
keyTakeaways: Keep a running 'news idioms' deck with spaced repetition.
Practice one-minute oral summaries from news clips.

notes.title: Precis & Composition: Solved Sets (Benchmark Only)
notes.content: Compare your attempts to worked solutions to gauge coverage, tone, and length. Don't memorize—analyze approach.
keyTakeaways: Checklist: central claim, logical order, proportionate compression.
Extract reusable sentence stems for neutral tone.

notes.title: Linking & Signposting Language (Academic)
notes.content: Use academic phrasebanks to vary transitions and signal logical relations cleanly in summaries/answers.
keyTakeaways: Rotate between stance, contrast, cause, exemplification frames.
Keep signposting short; avoid padding.

notes.title: Full-Stack Grammar Drills (Mixed Skills)
notes.content: Rotate weekly through clauses, modifiers, punctuation, reported speech, and parallelism with mixed sets.
keyTakeaways: Keep an error log by category; revisit weak areas.
Do a 10-question unit test to end each session.

resources.title: Khan Academy — SAT Grammar Practice (unit tests)

notes.title: Comprehension Extension: Nonfiction & Argument
notes.content: Collect longer nonfiction to practice précis + Q&A. Aim for diverse topics (science, society, policy).
keyTakeaways: One weekly 120-word précis from longform.
Track new terms; create definition + example.
